description: Compare Old French eskaper, eschapler (“to cut, hew”), Late Latin scapello. Compare scabble.

verbs.description: scapple (third-person singular simple present scapples, present participle scappling, simple past and past participle scappled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To work roughly, or shape without finishing, as stone before leaving the quarry.
(transitive) To dress (e.g. stone) in any way short of fine tooling or rubbing.
